topComments.author: Ionut Sendroiu
topComments.comment: (TraduÃ§Ã£o do Google) Dos trÃªs portÃµes fatÃ­midas que permaneceram de pÃ© hoje, Bab Zuwayla Ã© o mais dramÃ¡tico, com seus minaretes do sÃ©culo quinze. Leva os visitantes a um bairro bazar que Ã© tÃ£o cheio de vida hoje como era na Idade MÃ©dia. No inÃ­cio do perÃ­odo mameluco, os sultÃµes costumavam sentar-se na plataforma entre as duas torres para assistir Ã  procissÃ£o do Mahmal, o palanquim cerimonial que acompanhava a caravana anual de peregrinaÃ§Ã£o a Meca. No entanto, este portÃ£o tambÃ©m era um local para execuÃ§Ãµes pÃºblicas, e as cabeÃ§as dos criminosos eram exibidas acima dos portÃµes em estacas. AtÃ© Tumanbay, o Ãºltimo sultÃ£o mameluco do Egito, foi enforcado aqui em 1517, apÃ³s a conquista do paÃ­s pelos otomanos. A corda de Tumanbay quebrou nas duas primeiras tentativas antes que sua sorte acabasse. Seu corpo permaneceu suspenso do portÃ£o por trÃªs dias e depois foi enterrado. As vistas das torres sÃ£o espetaculares, embora parte do bairro esteja tristemente negligenciada.  (Original) Out of the three Fatimid gates that remained standing nowadays, Bab Zuwayla is the most dramatic, with its crowning fifteen-century minarets. It leads the visitors to a bazaar quarter that is as full of life today as it was in the Middle Age. In the early Mameluke period, the sultans used to sit on the platform between the two towers to watch the procession of the Mahmal, the ceremonial palanquin that accompanied the annual pilgrimage caravan to Mecca. However, this gate was also a place for public executions, and the heads of criminals were displayed above the gates on spikes. Even Tumanbay, the last Mameluke sultan of Egypt was hanged here in 1517, after the country's conquest by the Ottomans. Tumanbayâ€™s rope broke on the first two attempts before his luck ran out. His body remained suspended from the gate for three days and then was buried. The views from towers are spectacular, although part of the neighborhood is sadly neglected.
